text: Dr. Ray Peat and Contrary Pancake

Fun fact, but the Dr. Tom Brewer guy that Ray Peat always talks about proving preeclampsia can often be prevented with more salt and protein in the diet still has his website up even though he died 20 years ago. A lot of it is like a portal to the 1980s. Interesting for doctors.

I guess he sort of just won because one of his main ideas was that diuretics should not be used during pregnancy and eventually they did actually mostly stop using them. One page talks about PABA as a vitamin. You can see how much the entire field has changed with the decades.
>Finnish people have Counter-Strike sauna servers

For the record if the early "Cevitamic acid" supplements were effective at 15-25 mg, one glass of freshly squeezed orange juice contains ~125 mg. And there are supplements of acerola cherries. But maybe the product had some beneficial contaminant (like policosanols in Vitamin E).

Reading this you can notice two things:

1. Doctors were obsessed with trying to prevent women from gaining too much weight during pregnancy for some reason.

2. They loved low-sodium diets and tried to put every single pregnant woman on a forced low salt diet with zero rationale

It really is noteworthy just how retarded most medicine was until relatively recently. They just loved doing bizarrely bad stuff like giving various diuretics to pregnant women to make them lose weight, restricting random nutrients, telling them not to eat too much protein, etc.

I really respect people like this who have one favorite dish that they will always order no matter where with zero exceptions. For me it's the chocolate souffle with ice cream if I know it's made with real butter. I've even had it at gas stations. Also grilled cheese with honey.

If you travel a lot you can also trace the regional tastes and how they change with distance. For example with tripe soup if you start in Turkey it's going to be a lot oilier and rich in hot spices piled on top, in Romania it gets milder and they use horseradish instead, etc.
Beef liver can often be meh if overcooked or if it's not fresh, I like it but often ordering liver at non elite restaurants is disappointing. Tartare is impossible to fuck up
More of a Bulgarian regional thing I think

Reading the Dr. Tom Brewer diet stuff about how in the 20th century basically all pregnant women were put on a low calories diet (with low protein and salt) to prevent them from gaining weight is insanely blackpilling. Low birth weight limits your intellectual potential for life.

This was not just a few kooky docs, but standard ob/gyn practice even in the 70s. They yelled at pregnant women if they were gaining too much weight. Thousands of potential genius scientists and artists were probably lost because their potential was biologically limited for life.
drbrewerpregnancydiet dot com is a website that has collected a ton of info about that era, it was just idiocy
